'' he asked , ready to do whatever he could to help people . He may be small and bittersweet , but Tartok was always ready to help . <newline> ________________________________________ <newline> The man in front of Syphon was speaking in a primal language . Talia hoped that Syphon would be able to understand him . She was sent as a translator , having studied all the languages of their original home , what was called something like `` Terr '' or `` Ert , '' that were remembered . <newline> <newline> `` We were sent to this world , '' she said , `` in that ship . You are the first people of another planet we have ever talked to . Will you help us make peace ? '' she asked in the language they used on their home planet of Lœa . <newline> <newline> The man said something in the primal language , and Syphon told Talia , `` He 's willing to help , but he only partially understands us . Do you have the ICD ? '' Syphon asked . ICD stood for *Interplanetary Communication Device* . <newline> Talia stared at her , wordless . `` I ... I thought you had it , '' she said . <newline> <newline> Syphon 's face went a stark pallor , matching the blue-white ice . `` Jarak ! You have the ICD , right ? '' she asked . <newline> <newline> `` No , '' he said . `` Why ? Do n't one of <newline> you ... Oh shit , you guys forgot it , did n't you ? '' Jarak was not one to cuss unless the situation was dire , which this certainly was . If they could n't find it , they would n't be able to tell the Lœans what they had found ! They 'd be stuck in this icy wilderness for their entire lives ! <newline> <newline> `` Oh , shit shit shit , '' Jarak said . `` Um , it was in the cockpit , right ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Yeah , '' Talia said . `` How did I forget it ? '' she muttered . <newline> <newline> `` Okay , we need to go find it . Ask him if he has rope , '' Jarak said to Syphon . <newline> <newline> Syphon translated the message since the man did n't speak their own language . He replied in the same language , and Syphon said , `` He says he can understand me now and that he does have rope . He 's willing to help us . '' <newline> <newline> `` Tell him to go get the rope , and that we do n't need his help . We can scale the cliff and get it ourselves . '' Jarak said bitterly . <newline> <newline> As Syphon translated , Talia said , `` Why should n't we have his help ? He probably knows the cliff and water better than us , and if we 're going to establish stable connections to this planet we may as well start now . '' <newline> <newline> The man asked something and Syphon replied . He said something again , and Syphon said , `` He says he knows how to scale the cliff and how deep the water is at places . He wants to help . '' <newline> <newline> Jarak sighed . `` Fine , but tell him to hurry . '' <newline> ________________________________________ <newline> Tartok hurried to the shed where the dogs lived , just large enough for all of them and the ropes . He slammed open the door and some of the dogs looked up , bored . He grabbed the rope he used to tie them to the sled . It would be enough to scale the cliff , about fifteen meters ; not very tall unless the bottom is a tide pool of liquid ice with spiky rock at the bottom , poking up randomly . He took it and some of the bones from the dogs ' dinners . He crushed them into a crack in the ice where they held . He stepped on it , and it held him . He slammed another right behind it , trying the same test . If it held him , it would certainly hold the young , bitter man who had escaped the bird . The man was tall but thin , probably weighing a little more than Tartok himself . He tied the rope around the bones and told the translating woman , `` I am ready to go with the man . '' When she tells her crew , she replies , `` The man is not going . The other woman is . '' <newline> <newline> Tartok is shocked . Surely the man is the captain of the crew ? <newline> <newline> It does not matter much . These people are from some far odd land and need help . They have different customs . Tartok is not one to judge . <newline> <newline> `` Okay , '' he says as the translator relays his message . `` Let 's get to work . ''

prompt: After Earth is destroyed , the surviving humans colonize two different planets . All contact between the two groups was lost , until they rediscover each other thousands of years later .
story:
The sky was a deep, bruised purple, like a bruise that refused to heal. It was a color that seemed to seep into the very marrow of the bones, a reminder of the world that once was. The twin planets, Arkeia and Kyrios, hung like two lanterns in the void, their once-blue skies now a dull, ashen grey.

On Arkeia, the humans had built a new world, one that was both familiar and strange. The cities were sprawling, organic growths that seemed to have sprouted from the very earth itself. The air was thick with the scent of blooming flowers, and the sound of gentle music drifted on the breeze. It was a world of beauty, of wonder, and of loss.

On Kyrios, the humans had built a different kind of world. The cities were cold, angular, and unforgiving. The air was thin and crisp, and the only sound was the soft hum of machinery. It was a world of steel and stone, of precision and control.

For thousands of years, the two groups had lived in silence, each unaware of the other's existence. They had built their own cultures, their own histories, and their own mythologies. They had forgotten the world that once was, the world that had been lost in the cataclysmic event that had destroyed Earth.

But then, one day, something changed. A faint signal, a whisper of a message, began to echo across the void. It was a message of hope, of longing, and of recognition. The humans on Arkeia and Kyrios looked up at the stars, and saw each other for the first time in millennia.

The first contact was tentative, a series of cautious exchanges that were both exhilarating and terrifying. The humans on Arkeia were awestruck by the sheer scale of the cities on Kyrios, the towering spires and grand architecture that seemed to defy gravity. The humans on Kyrios were equally amazed by the beauty of Arkeia, the lush forests and sparkling waterfalls that seemed to dance in the breeze.

As the two groups began to communicate, they discovered that they had more in common than they initially thought. They shared a common history, a common culture, and a common desire to rebuild and restart. They began to exchange knowledge, ideas, and stories, and slowly but surely, they began to rebuild their world.

The humans on Arkeia brought with them the memories of the past, the stories of the world that once was. They brought with them the music of the spheres, the poetry of the ages, and the laughter of the children. The humans on Kyrios brought with them the precision of the machines, the logic of the equations, and the beauty of the mathematics.

As the two groups merged, they created something new, something beautiful, and something strange. They created a world that was both familiar and unknown, a world that was both beautiful and brutal. They created a world that was full of hope, full of wonder, and full of possibility.

And as they looked up at the stars, they knew that they were not alone. They knew that they were part of something greater, something that transcended the boundaries of time and space. They knew that they were part of a universe that was full of mystery, full of wonder, and full of possibility.

prompt: Every authority is baffled but for the past few years everyone has been receiving a Christmas present . To some delight and others horror , the gifts are based on how 'good ' you 've been .
story: Despite parents having said it for generations , * '' What did Santa get you ? `` * took on a whole new meaning on Christmas day , 2015 . <newline> <newline> On a day when the TVs around the country were usually playing Christmas songs from the 70 's , they were now fixed on the news channels , all with `` BREAKING NEWS '' banners flashing across the screen . Reports of robberies , with no sign of forced entry and cries over invasion of privacy , yet with no-one quite sure what it was of their privacy that was invaded . The only thing that was crystal clear was that during the night of Christmas eve , someone had entered each person 's home and placed presents under the tree . Not just randomly either . Each present was labeled and each mother , father and child in the home was accounted for . <newline> <newline> It took a while for some to notice , usually the families where the parents teased their children by delaying the gifts promising excitement and joy , but by midday everyone had discovered one extra present per person . Most children received expensive toys or video games and adults sometimes even found a new car parked outside ; keys in the ignition and a green tree hanging from the rear view mirror . <newline> <newline> Not everyone was happy though . Some had woken up on Christmas day to find something entirely different and unpleasant . Liars searched for their present only to find rotten fish , wrapped and pushed under floorboards . Men and women who had cheated on their spouses unwrapped their gifts to find naked action figures ; seemingly innocent enough but when picked up they would begin to reel off intimate details of their affairs while their partner was in the room . Needless to say , it was these very people who were shouting the loudest and writing to their local papers the quickest . <newline> <newline> The government was quick to step in , with the prime minister appearing outside his home in the late afternoon to speak to the nation . He spoke with countless microphones extended towards his face , but managed to keep his eyes on the camera placed dead center . <newline> <newline> * '' Good evening everyone . There does n't seem to be a single family across the nation who has n't been visited by 'Santa ' '' * he began , raising and bending two fingers to emphasize the fictional character . * '' I assure everyone that the government and I are doing our utmost to figure out what is going on , and to determine who is behind all of this . We ask for your patience as we begin our investigation . Please try to enjoy the rest of your Christmas ! `` * Without further comment , the PM waved as he retreated back into his home , where his staff awaited him . <newline> <newline> * '' God dammit , Linda . Find out what is going on ! `` * , the PM demanded as he threw off the reindeer knit his staff insisted he wear . <newline> <newline> Linda replied promptly , following the PM through to his office . * '' Of course , Sir . We have local law enforcement around the country inspecting people 's homes . I 'm not sure what we 're expecting to find though . Could it really be him ? * '' <newline> <newline> The head of the country stopped in his tracks , spun on his heels and stared straight into his assistant 's eyes for several moments without saying a word . Just as she was about to apologize , he stepped towards her , forcing her to step backwards towards the door . <newline> <newline> * '' Listen . I do n't care WHO did it . I do n't care WHY they did it . All I WANT is for the responsible party to be found and for their trespassin ' asses to be nailed to the wall . Am I clear ? `` * <newline> <newline> Linda , who was now half way out into the corridor , apologized profusely and span on her own heels and walked straight into the staff office . The PM adjusted the collar around his neck as he watched her scuttle away , then stormed back into his own office , locking the door behind him . <newline> <newline> He paced up and down the room , the heels of his shoes clicking off the hardwood flooring . He spent some time texting old friends in the police force , asking if they had any leads . When they did n't reply at a moment 's notice he threw his phone against the sofa at the back of the room . He eventually got tired of walking and returned to his desk where he had spent the whole morning before his staff demanded he speak to the press . <newline> <newline> Opening the drawer he pulled out a small box , wrapped in what seemed to be white wrapping paper with thin black lines . Upon closer inspection those lines were actually text from emails which the PM had written . Emails which should n't have seen the light of day . He held the box in his hands for several minutes , not reading what it had been wrapped in as he already knew it was all the information that would end his career . A career built upon bribes , deceit and some things much worse . With a heavy sigh he pushed his thumbs against the lid of the box and let it fall to the floor . <newline> <newline> The inside of the box was also lined with printed emails but in the center sat the hairband which he gave to his daughter the Christmas before he was elected . The daughter who was supposed to be on holiday , but who was now not answering her phone or emails . <newline> <newline> The PM sat at his desk with no holiday cheer around him , knowing that he had received , to put it lightly , the worst Christmas present in the country . Strangely it was n't the present or even his missing child that was haunting him the most . <newline> <newline> It was knowing that he had deserved it . <newline> <newline> -- -- -- - <newline> <newline> First writing prompt attempt ! Enjoy ! <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline>

prompt: Every authority is baffled but for the past few years everyone has been receiving a Christmas present . To some delight and others horror , the gifts are based on how 'good ' you 've been .
story:
The snowflakes danced in the air like a chorus of mischievous sprites, their delicate forms dissolving into a million tiny mirrors that reflected the faces of the townspeople. It was Christmas morning, and the air was alive with the hum of anticipation. But amidst the joy and cheer, a sense of unease hung like a thin veil, a reminder that this year's festivities would be unlike any other.

For the past few years, a mysterious force had been bestowing gifts upon the residents of this small town. At first, it was dismissed as a prank, a clever ruse to bring some levity to the holiday season. But as the gifts continued to arrive, each one tailored to the individual's behavior, it became clear that something more sinister was at play.

The first gift of the season had been a small, exquisite music box, its delicate ballerina twirling to the tune of a haunting melody. It had been delivered to the doorstep of Mrs. Jenkins, a kind-hearted woman who had spent the past year volunteering at the local soup kitchen. The music box had been a beautiful gesture, but one that had also raised questions about the true nature of the gifts.

As the days passed, more gifts arrived, each one a reflection of the recipient's actions. A young boy who had been caught bullying his classmates received a toy robot that shot laser beams, a cruel reminder of his own behavior. A couple who had been caught arguing in public received a set of fine china, a symbol of their own domestic discord.

But it was the gifts that brought joy to those who had been good that were the most puzzling. A group of friends who had spent the year volunteering at a local animal shelter received a set of rare, exotic pets, their faces lighting up with delight as they accepted their gifts. A single mother who had worked tirelessly to provide for her family received a beautiful, handmade quilt, its intricate patterns and colors a testament to the love and care that had gone into its creation.

As the townspeople gathered in the town square to exchange their gifts, a sense of unease settled over the crowd. Who was behind this mysterious phenomenon, and what did they hope to achieve? Was it a twisted game, designed to punish the wicked and reward the good? Or was it something more complex, a commentary on the nature of morality and the human condition?

As the gifts were opened and the reactions ranged from delight to horror, one thing became clear: this was no ordinary Christmas. It was a time of reckoning, a moment when the true nature of the town's residents was laid bare. And as the snowflakes continued to fall, gently covering the town in a layer of white, it seemed that the true gift of the season was not the presents themselves, but the chance to confront the darkness within.

The music box, now silent, sat on the edge of the town square, its delicate ballerina frozen in time. It was a reminder that the true gift of Christmas was not the presents, but the chance to reflect on the past year, to confront the choices we had made, and to strive for a better tomorrow. As the townspeople dispersed, each one carrying their own unique gift, it was clear that this was a Christmas that would be remembered for years to come, a time of reckoning and redemption.

prompt: What 's on the tape ?
story: `` Is that it ? '' He sighed . `` Yeah . I hate watching these . '' `` It 's necessary . We have to know . '' Bob pushed the tape into the TV/VCR player that was all the department could afford . Up on the screen appeared a little boy , about three , clutching a teddy bear . `` Do n't . Please , not again ! '' The close ups were the worst . He reviewed it all . `` We have it . It 's all we need . '' Another day , another perp . One day , one day , we wo n't have to do this any more , thought Bob . If the medicine works , we 'll never have to do this again . He sighed , and for the last time , picked up the phone . `` Pick him up . He 's ours . '' The last man to be arrested for that hideous crime would be the first treated with the new cure .

prompt: What 's on the tape ?
story:
The old VHS player sat on the dusty shelf, its plastic casing a faded pink that seemed to bleed into the surrounding air. It was a relic of a bygone era, a reminder of late-night movie marathons and family gatherings that had long since lost their luster. But it was the tape itself that held the real mystery.

Lena's fingers trembled as she carefully removed the tape from its cardboard sleeve, the hiss of static filling the air as she inserted it into the player. The screen flickered to life, casting a warm glow over the cluttered room. A title appeared, scrawled in messy handwriting: "The Last Memory of Summer '95".

Lena's eyes widened as the tape began to play, the grainy footage unfolding like a forgotten photograph. It was a home movie, shot on a sweltering summer afternoon, the sun beating down on the camera like a malevolent force. A group of children, their faces smeared with dirt and sweat, laughed and played in the background, their carefree joy a stark contrast to the sense of unease that settled in the pit of Lena's stomach.

As the tape progressed, the camera panned across a makeshift picnic blanket, the children's laughter and shouts mingling with the distant hum of a lawnmower. But it was the figure in the distance that caught Lena's attention – a girl with a messy bob and a faded sundress, her eyes fixed intently on something in the distance.

The camera zoomed in, the image blurring as the tape skipped and stuttered. Lena's heart quickened as the girl's face came into focus, her eyes locked onto something that seemed to be... watching her. The air seemed to vibrate with tension, the children's laughter dying on their lips as they too turned to gaze at the mysterious figure.

The tape continued to play, the footage growing increasingly distorted and fragmented. The girl's face appeared and disappeared, her eyes never leaving the camera. It was as if she was trying to convey a message, but the words were lost in the static.

Lena's skin crawled as the tape finally came to a stop, the screen flickering back to black. She felt a shiver run down her spine as she realized that the girl's eyes had been fixed on her own face, her expression a mixture of fear and recognition.

The room seemed to grow darker, the shadows cast by the fading light twisting into grotesque shapes. Lena's mind reeled as she tried to make sense of the footage, the girl's eyes burning into her memory like a branding iron.

It was then that she saw it – a small, almost imperceptible message scrawled on the edge of the tape, the words "Don't watch again" etched in a handwriting that seemed to match the title on the tape.

Lena's heart sank as she realized that she had uncovered a secret, a hidden truth that was meant to remain buried. The tape had been left for her, a message from someone who knew that some memories were better left forgotten. And as she gazed at the VHS player, now silent and still, she knew that she would never look at the world in the same way again.

prompt: Write a story that is perfectly normal , until the last line .
story: `` Aw , do n't cry my sweet little girl ! You were so quiet earlier , even with all the racket my friends made ! '' <newline> Shrill screams and crocodile tears stream from her face , unrelenting . She 's heavy . <newline> `` Oh do you have a full poopie bag ? Is that why you 're crying ? I might just have to take care of this before I can finish cleaning the living room . Such a poopie monster , are n't you . '' <newline> `` Now , where did your mommy put those clean poo holders ? '' <newline> He rummages through the shelves . Empty bottles and bottle caps . He grabs the wet naps and baby powder then turns to the closet nearby . <newline> `` There they are . Do n't worry sweet thing , you 'll be clean and tidy before you know it . I 'm a cleaner by trade , and I 'm the best . '' <newline> He sets her on the changing table and begins his dirty work . Tossing out the old diaper . Grabbing a fresh wet one and tidying up the tiny butt cheeks , covered in muck . A dash of baby powder . Then the fresh diaper , brand new . <newline> The crying dies down . <newline> `` There you are sweetheart . Nice and clean . '' <newline> He picks her up and cradles her in his arms , gently . She 's almost asleep again . <newline> `` Hush little baby , do n't say a word ... '' he sings softly as he places her back in her crib and begins to rock her back to sleep . <newline> When the lullaby is over , he steps back to admire his work . <newline> `` No child should die screaming , `` he said as he reaches for the same gun he executed her parents with .

prompt: Write a story that is perfectly normal , until the last line .
story:
It was a typical Wednesday morning in the small town of Willow Creek. The sun was shining, casting a warm glow over the quaint streets and homes. The smell of freshly baked bread wafted from the local bakery, enticing the sleepy residents to start their day. In the midst of this tranquility, Emma sat at her kitchen table, sipping her coffee and staring out the window.

She was a 30-year-old graphic designer, working from home to balance her creative pursuits with the demands of her 9-to-5 job. Her days blended together in a haze of deadlines, meetings, and endless cups of coffee. But on this particular morning, something felt different. Maybe it was the way the sunlight danced through the leaves of the trees, casting intricate patterns on the sidewalk. Or perhaps it was the sound of birds singing in perfect harmony, their melodies intertwining like the threads of a rich tapestry.

As she gazed out the window, Emma's mind began to wander. She thought about her childhood, growing up in this very town, playing in the same streets and parks she now walked by every day. She remembered the smell of her mother's cooking, the feel of her father's rough hands guiding her through the woods behind their house. The memories came flooding back, and for a moment, Emma felt like she was a child again, carefree and full of wonder.

The morning wore on, and Emma settled into her routine. She worked on her latest project, a logo design for a local business, and took a break to grab a sandwich from the deli down the street. As she walked, she noticed the way the sunlight reflected off the dew-kissed grass, creating a thousand tiny diamonds that sparkled like fireflies on a summer night.

As the day drew to a close, Emma packed up her things and headed home, feeling a sense of satisfaction with the work she'd accomplished. She spent the evening curled up on her couch, watching the stars twinkle to life outside her window. And as she drifted off to sleep, she felt a deep sense of contentment, knowing that she was exactly where she was meant to be.

But as she slipped into the darkness, her eyes caught a glimpse of something that made her heart skip a beat. On the wall opposite her bed, in letters that seemed to pulse with a life of their own, was scrawled a single, chilling phrase: "You're not who you think you are."

prompt: Even with all the stars on the sky , the night will always remain dark .
story: The feast had been going on for days but there was no end in sight . It was not just the celebration of two people joining each other for a lifetime of happiness , it was four decades of constant warfare coming to an end . <newline> <newline> What started as a feud between to minor leudes escalated to the most terrible war the kingdoms had seen since the dawn of men . Fourty years of murder , rape and pillaging had devastated the land and the people alike , yet the table was richly set and the wine was flowing like the blood of those who had given their life for this peace . <newline> <newline> The marriage of Emperor Aldwyn II , Lordprotecter of the realm and Earl of the Lowlands to Winifred of Princess of the mountain peak , Lady of the narrow county was truly an event to be celebrated . Aldwyn had been sceptical of his bride . He was a young man and not a too bad looking one at that . His uncle had arranged this marriage before his death as part of a peace agreement between the two kingdoms . And he was happy about the peace , no doubt . But peace at the price of his life ? There were rumors about the Princess , her father was an old man after all and her mother one of the cave people . They were not exactly renowned for their beauty and gentle souls . <newline> His concerns were washed away when her father unveiled her before the altar . She was a stunning woman with eyes in a green Aldwyn had never seen before and hair in fiery red . When her lips curled to a timid smile Aldwyn fell in love . The next three days went by in a haze . He barely slept , but he did not mind . Drunk from the wine in his cup and the woman on his lap the young Emperor danced and feasted and dined like had had not since his own father fell at the sacking of Oldtown . He swore to himself he would one day be a better father , unlike the fool that raised him . And now he had the wife who would carry his beatiful offspring , future empires of not only the Lowlands , the Shire and the moors but also the Mountains Peak and the Narrow Land . He wondered what he would name them , as their names would go down in history for eternity . <newline> <newline> But as the third day went Aldwyns lust grew . Winifred had teased him since he carried her down the stairs of the cathedral and soon he would take what was rightfully his . He grabbed her arm and pulled her close to his face . Accidentally tainting her white dress with his wine colored saliva he whispered in her ear and the two went off to his quarters . He ripped her dress in two as the door closed behind him , pushing her onto the bed . He needed this and he would take it now . <newline> As he pinned her down a thought arose in his head . This was not some whore he had picked up in an alley , fearing for her life as she complied , this was his wife . <newline> <newline> He froze for a moment , searching for something romantic to say . `` You 're not as ugly as the rumors say '' , he spat out . She seemed unimpressed . He pulled himself off her and in a moment of poetic clearness he muttered : `` You are the stars on my sky , lighting the way home . '' Caressing her face he went for a kiss and was greeted by the point of a dagger penetrating his ribs . <newline> `` Even with all the stars on the sky , the night will always remain dark . `` , she whispered in his ear . She waited for the blood to dripple out of his mouth , then shoved the Emperors lifeless body off herself . The assassin covered herself with a cloak laying near the bed and held for a moment . She had all the time in the world , her husband was not expected for another hour and with the feast going on she would have no trouble escaping . <newline> What a fool she thought to herself as she climbed past the windowframe . He was right in one way though , Princess Winifred truly is as ugly as the rumors say .

prompt: Even with all the stars on the sky , the night will always remain dark .
story:
In the velvety expanse of the night sky, a million twinkling lights danced like fireflies on a summer evening, their gentle sparkle weaving an intricate tapestry of wonder. The stars, a celestial showcase of diamonds and sapphires, shone with a fierce radiance, as if the universe itself was a great, glittering canvas, painted with the brushstrokes of creation. And yet, amidst this dazzling display of light, a profound truth remained hidden: the night would always remain dark.

Ava stood at the edge of the lake, the water's surface reflecting the starry sky above like a mirror. She breathed in the cool, damp air, feeling the misty veil of night settle around her like a shroud. The world was bathed in a soft, ethereal glow, as if the stars had seeped into the very marrow of the earth. But Ava knew that this was an illusion – a fleeting respite from the darkness that lurked beneath.

She thought of her grandmother, who had once told her that the night was not just the absence of light, but a presence in its own right. "The night is a womb," she had said, "where the world is reborn, and the stars are the midwives of the darkness." Ava had never quite understood what she meant, but as she stood there, surrounded by the starry expanse, she felt a shiver run down her spine. The night was indeed a womb, a place of mystery and transformation, where the old was shed and the new was born.

As she gazed out at the lake, Ava saw the ripples on the water's surface, like the gentle lapping of waves against the shore. She saw the trees, their branches etched against the sky like a delicate pen and ink drawing. And she saw the darkness, a palpable, living thing that seeped into every pore of her being. It was a darkness that was both beautiful and terrifying, a reminder that the light was not the only thing that existed in the world.

Ava felt a sense of peace settle over her, a sense of acceptance that the night would always remain dark, no matter how many stars shone in the sky. It was a reminder that the world was a complex, multifaceted place, full of contradictions and paradoxes. The light and the darkness, the order and the chaos – they were all intertwined, like the threads of a rich tapestry.

As she stood there, the stars twinkling above her like a celestial showcase, Ava felt a sense of connection to the universe, a sense of belonging to something much larger than herself. The night was a mystery, a riddle that she would never fully understand, but she was content to stand in its darkness, surrounded by the stars, and let the universe unfold its secrets before her. For in the end, it was not the light that mattered, but the darkness – the darkness that made the light shine all the brighter, and the stars twinkle with a fierce, otherworldly beauty.

prompt: You dress up as the `` classic '' reaper for a Halloween party -- black robe , toy scythe , all that jazz . Midway through the night , you hear a deep , dark voice in your head ... `` I need a sick day , man , and you look like the perfect person to take my place ... Your costume is almost perfect , after all . ''
story: Death waits for no man . That 's another way of saying the vacation package was absolute shit and the dental plan left a lot to be desired . Thankfully he was able to get his shift covered and take some well deserved time off during Halloween , he did n't even have to buy a costume . He knocked on Tom 's door with a big grin on his face , which was entirely coincidental but this time his skeletal visage *meant* it . Amanda let him in with a wave of her hand . <newline> <newline> `` Tom 's in the drawing room . May I get you two something to drink ? '' <newline> <newline> `` ... ... ... .. '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh . Uh , well I 'll just grab a coffee for Tom shall I ? '' <newline> <newline> Death passed silently into the drawing room , where an overweight business intelligence consultant was pouring over scrolls crossed out with red pen . <newline> <newline> `` Should n't have survived Woodstock . Has literally no immune system . Professional ninety-year-old basejumper *oh COME ON . * You 're here , good , take a seat . Seven failed suicide attempts despite trying her best ... <newline> <newline> Death hovered uncertainly at the door until Tom 's impatient waving brought him down to a wicker deckchair . Eventually the style pen was thrown against a litany of crossed names and corrections . Tom 's eyes met the hollow pools of darkness that seemed angled slightly downwards towards the floor . <newline> <newline> `` Cinco de mayo . Explain . '' <newline> <newline> `` ... ... .. '' <newline> <newline> `` Right well I 'll tell you what it is . It 's a bloody *disgrace* is what it is . Talking to the departed ? Welcoming home the ghosts of your ancestors ? As in , what are you even *for ? * '' <newline> <newline> Death stared without comment . <newline> <newline> `` In the past two hundred years everyone 's life expectancy has been booming out of control and you do n't even have the common decency to put a stop to it . I saw a lady who was a hundred and twenty ! A hundred and *twenty ! * I had to personally apologize for the delay and might I say she was *not* happy to see me . '' <newline> <newline> Tom shuffled the papers and dumped them onto Death 's lap . <newline> <newline> `` I 've prepared your itinerary for the following year . The whole world should have entered a global warming ice age three years ago and we have a *lot* of catching up to do if we 're going to make the antibiotics shortage before June . '' <newline> <newline> `` ... ... ... . '' <newline> <newline> Death grinned .

prompt: You dress up as the `` classic '' reaper for a Halloween party -- black robe , toy scythe , all that jazz . Midway through the night , you hear a deep , dark voice in your head ... `` I need a sick day , man , and you look like the perfect person to take my place ... Your costume is almost perfect , after all . ''
story:
The velvet blackness of my reaper costume seemed to swallow me whole, like a shroud of forgotten memories. I adjusted the hood, the tattered edges of the robe fluttering like the wings of a raven. The toy scythe, a gaudy prop, felt heavy in my grasp, a symbol of the harvest I was here to reap. The party was in full swing, a cacophony of laughter and music that threatened to consume me whole.

As I mingled with the other revelers, a sense of detachment began to creep over me. The faces blurred together, their features indistinguishable from one another. I felt like a ghost, a specter haunting the edges of the party. The music pulsed through my veins, a rhythmic heartbeat that seemed to synchronize with the thrumming of my own mortality.

And then, it started. A low, raspy voice, like the rustling of dry leaves, whispered in my ear. "I need a sick day, man, and you look like the perfect person to take my place." The words sent a shiver down my spine, a cold sweat breaking out on my forehead. I spun around, but there was no one there. The voice seemed to come from within, a dark and ancient presence that lurked just beneath the surface of my mind.

I tried to shake off the feeling, telling myself it was just the beer talking. But the voice persisted, its words echoing in my mind like a mantra. "You look like the perfect person to take my place." The costume, the scythe, the very act of being a reaper seemed to take on a new significance. I was no longer just a partygoer, but a vessel, a proxy for some unknown force.

As the night wore on, the voice grew louder, more insistent. I felt myself becoming a puppet, my strings being pulled by an unseen hand. The music and laughter seemed to fade into the background, replaced by a sense of creeping dread. I was no longer in control, but a mere pawn in some dark and sinister game.

And then, the voice spoke again, its words dripping with malevolence. "You're almost perfect, after all." The costume seemed to tighten around me, the black robe constricting my chest like a noose. I felt a sense of suffocation, as if I was being slowly strangled by the very fabric of my own existence.

I tried to scream, but my voice was trapped in my throat. The partygoers seemed to fade away, leaving me alone with the voice. The scythe felt heavy in my grasp, a symbol of the harvest that was to come. I was no longer just a reaper, but a harbinger of death itself. And in that moment, I knew that I was doomed.
