story: `` You think it 's this place that kills you ? No . It has n't been lethal for over 11000 years . No , that 's not it . It 's us that do . '' <newline> <newline> A rock hit the temple of his head and first a pain and then a dull , pulsing feeling accompanied him to the void . <newline> <newline> The man left standing cursed to himself . <newline> <newline> `` God damn idiot . God damn machine . Shit . Shit . SHIT . It was only a few days on that planet . Two god damm days . '' <newline> <newline> A tear formed and fell . It was only a couple of months more of collecting weakly radioactive material but it seemed like an eternity .

prompt: 12.000 years in the future . Civilizations fell and rose . Technology back on renaissance level . Mysterious area where no one can survive . Turns out to be Chernobyl .
story:
In the year 12,000, the world was a tapestry of forgotten lore and half-remembered myths. The great civilizations that once spanned the globe had long since crumbled, leaving behind only whispers of their grandeur. The air was thick with the whispers of the past, as if the very earth itself was a repository of ancient secrets.

Aria, a young apprentice to the revered Cartographer of the Ancients, stood at the edge of a vast, uncharted expanse. The map before her depicted a region so shrouded in mystery that even the most skilled navigators dared not venture near. They called it the "Devouring Mire," a place where the very fabric of reality seemed to unravel.

Rumors spoke of a cursed land, where the skies raged with perpetual storms and the ground trembled with unseen terrors. Some said it was a realm of the damned, where the spirits of the dead roamed free. Others whispered that it was a testing ground, a proving ground for the worthy and the unwary alike.

Aria's curiosity was piqued, and she felt an insatiable urge to unravel the secrets of the Devouring Mire. She assembled a team of brave and skilled explorers, each with their own unique expertise. There was Jax, the cunning thief; Lila, the enigmatic alchemist; and Kael, the battle-hardened warrior.

Together, they set out into the unknown, their footsteps echoing through the stillness. The air grew thick with an otherworldly energy, as if the very land itself was watching them. The team pressed on, driven by a mix of trepidation and wonder.

As they delved deeper into the Mire, the landscape shifted and twisted, like a living, breathing entity. The ground beneath their feet gave way to a vast, barren expanse of twisted metal and concrete. Aria's eyes widened as she beheld the ruins of a city, its buildings twisted and deformed, as if they had been melted by some unseen force.

And then, they saw it: a massive, concrete sarcophagus, its surface scarred and pockmarked. The air around it seemed to vibrate with an eerie, pulsating energy. Lila, ever the scholar, recognized the symbol etched into the side of the sarcophagus – the mark of the Chernobyl disaster.

Aria's team exchanged uneasy glances, their faces pale with a mix of fear and awe. They had heard the stories, of course, but nothing could have prepared them for the reality of the Devouring Mire. The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, a place where the laws of nature seemed to bend and warp, was a realm of unutterable horror.

As they stood there, frozen in terror, the air around them began to shift and swirl. The storms that had been brewing on the horizon coalesced into a maelstrom of wind and rain, threatening to consume them whole. Aria knew that they had to leave, to flee the Mire before it was too late.

But as they turned to depart, they realized that they were not alone. A figure, shrouded in shadows, stood watching them from the edge of the ruins. Aria felt a shiver run down her spine as the figure stepped forward, its eyes glowing with an otherworldly light.

"Welcome to the Devouring Mire," it said, its voice like a sigh on the wind. "You will never leave."

prompt: A time traveller interviews major historical figures at three points in their lives : Their 16th birthday , the day after they made their most important decision , and the day before they die .
story: `` What do you want to be when you grow up ? '' Robert McCallister did n't care for the question any more than I did , but such mundane questions were necessary to sell the disguise . He was n't looking at me , he was looking through me , demonstrating his complete indifference to my presence . Of all the great kings and ruthless tyrants I 've interviewed throughout the ages , I had never felt as nervous , as intimidated , as I felt now . By a boy none-the-less ! Today I was playing school counselor for the boy that would invent the time machine . I did n't even attempt to stop him as he walked out of the office . Talking had never been one of my strong points , but this interview had crashed before it ever started . I may have failed this time , but I could n't stop my smile if I tried . Next week I 'd be there watching as he announced to the world his machine was a success ! What a day ! <newline> <newline> Today is the day ! The man who is to be my final subject , my grand finale ! Not a single open seat in the stadium , and yet there was not a whisper to be heard . How fortunate I am to have gained backstage access , and even more so , his promise of some one-on-one time . I had heard the speech a thousand times before , everyone from my timeline had . This was the day that changed the world . I had no need to be there , I had a job to do and I had to be ready . The applause resonating through the wall was enough to tell me his speech had come to a close , and my second chance was fast approaching . My tie was straight . My thoughts were clear . Pen was ready . I was prepared . But he was gone . Next week I had one more chance , one more opportunity . Next week would be this man 's last moments . I was scared . <newline> <newline> Time is a funny thing , you can see into the future or you can explore the past , but no matter how hard you tried , fate would remain fate . I 've known this day would come since I started my travels , yet I still feel so ill-prepared . It is the day the great Robert McCallister would die . A man who had seen eternity in his short 34 years , taken out by a drunk driver . here comes the truck now ! I had so much to ask , but could n't think of a thing to say . I knew it was coming . I was never good with dialogue , but I thought this time I was prepared ! There was n't much time , I had enough for a single question . I have to ask something ! `` How can a man interview his-damned-self ? ! ''

prompt: A time traveller interviews major historical figures at three points in their lives : Their 16th birthday , the day after they made their most important decision , and the day before they die .
story:
The Time Traveler's Tapestry

As I stepped through the swirling vortex, the air around me dissolved into a kaleidoscope of colors, leaving me breathless and disoriented. When my vision cleared, I found myself standing in the midst of a bustling marketplace, surrounded by the sounds and smells of 16th-century Florence. I had been given a rare gift – the chance to interview three of history's most influential figures at pivotal moments in their lives.

My first subject was Leonardo da Vinci, the Renaissance master, on the eve of his 16th birthday. I found him in his family's workshop, surrounded by half-finished sculptures and sketches of flying machines. His eyes sparkled with curiosity as I asked him about his dreams and aspirations. "I am but a vessel for the muses," he replied, his hands moving deftly as he worked on a delicate wooden model. "The world is a canvas, and I am but a brush, waiting to be guided by the winds of inspiration."

As we spoke, I noticed a faint smudge of paint on his cheek, a testament to his nocturnal creative sessions. His thoughts were already turning to the future, to the innovations that would soon make him a household name. I sensed a sense of restlessness, a feeling that the world was waiting for him to unlock its secrets.

The next day, I found myself in the presence of Albert Einstein, the brilliant physicist, on the morning after he made the fateful decision to pursue a career in science. We sat in a small café in Bern, Switzerland, surrounded by the quiet hum of conversation. His eyes were haunted by the weight of his own doubts, as if the universe itself was whispering secrets in his ear. "I was lost in the labyrinth of my own mind," he confessed, his voice barely above a whisper. "But then, like a thread of gold, the theory of relativity emerged, illuminating the path ahead."

As we spoke, I watched him scribble equations on a napkin, the symbols and formulas flowing from his mind like a river. His thoughts were a maelstrom of curiosity and wonder, driven by a passion to unravel the mysteries of the universe. I sensed a sense of trepidation, a feeling that the world was not yet ready for his groundbreaking ideas.

My final subject was Martin Luther King Jr., the civil rights leader, on the eve of his assassination. We sat in a small hotel room in Memphis, surrounded by the quiet murmur of his entourage. His eyes were weary, his spirit worn down by the relentless struggle for justice. "I am but a vessel for the voices of the marginalized," he said, his voice laced with a deep sadness. "The world is a tapestry, woven from the threads of hope and despair. I have seen the beauty of humanity, but also the ugliness of our own darkness."

As we spoke, I watched him gaze out the window, his eyes fixed on the city below. His thoughts were a jumble of memories, of triumphs and tragedies, of the countless faces he had seen and the countless lives he had touched. I sensed a sense of resignation, a feeling that the world was not yet ready to hear his message of love and equality.

As I prepared to leave, I realized that these three men, at three pivotal moments in their lives, had been given a rare gift – the chance to see the world through the eyes of others. They had been given a glimpse of the tapestry that was humanity, with all its beauty and ugliness, its triumphs and tragedies. And in that moment, they had been changed forever, their lives forever woven into the fabric of history.

His mother , gone with . Another miracle . <newline> <newline> Now I am sixty two . I am an old man . I have lived and loved and now , I do n't have time left . Sixty two and I feel ninety . <newline> <newline> I have nothing left to me . <newline> <newline> Except a gift . <newline> <newline> This girl is a drug addict . She is twenty three . She lays before me with no breath in her lungs . She is dead . <newline> <newline> I stare down at her . <newline> <newline> I lay my hand on her forehead . <newline> <newline> I can feel the life ready to leave my body . This is the last I have to give . <newline> <newline> Her eyes burst open , she sucks in air , she looks at me in terror . <newline> <newline> `` Second chance . '' <newline> <newline> I say . We have but a moment . I close my eyes and feel everything leave my body and soul . My Gift . My life . <newline> <newline> I am going to see my wife .
